Calculator

The Calculator class contains the framework for user plugin interactions using data classes CalculatorContext and CalculatorCommand

class symcalc.Calculator(context=None, command_prefix='/')

An interactive console containing plugins and the console

Initializes the calculator

Parameters

  • context (CalculatorContext) – The context that the calculator will use. If None, a new context will be generated. Defaults to None

  • command_prefix (str) – The prefix for commands to be interpreted as setting toggles. Defaults to "/"

notify_plugins_parse(command_data)
notify_plugins_command(command_data)
notify_plugins_resend(command_data)
notify_plugins_syntax_error(command_data)
notify_plugins_runtime_error(command_data)
notify_plugins_success(command_data)
notify_plugins_fail(command_data)

Notify all plugins of a command to be parsed. The given command_data can be modified in place to direct the calculator to perform subsequent actions. See CalculatorCommand

Parameters

command_data (CalculatorCommand) – The command which triggered this event

handle_error_output(data)

Method for handling stderr output written to the console interpreter. The data is generally passed to plugins.

Parameters

data (str) – The data written to stderr

Return type

None

register_plugin(plugin)

Register the given plugin

Parameters

plugin (CalculatorPlugin) – The plugin to register

Returns

self for chaining

Return type

Calculator

mksym(s, /, **kwargs)

Makes symbol(s) in the calculator context

Parameters

s (str) – Either a single word or a comma/space separated string containing multiple words. All words are created as a symbol in the CalculatorContext

Returns

The symbol or list of symbols that were created

Return type

Symbol | tuple[Symbol]

getsym(s)

Gets a variable in the calculator context

Parameters

s (str) – The variable to retrieve from the calculator context

Raises

KeyError – The given variable name was not found in the calculator context

Returns

The retrieved variable

Return type

Any

chksym(s)

Checks if a variable exists in the calculator context

Parameters

s (str) – The variable to check in the calculator context

Returns

Whether the variable was found

Return type

bool

reset()

Throws away the buffer from previous commands

Return type

None

command(command)

Push a command to the calculator.

Parameters

command (str) – The command to be pushed to the calculator

Returns

True if more input is required to complete the command, False otherwise. See code.InteractiveConsole

Return type

bool

interpret(line)

Interpret the given line as input

Parameters

line (str) – The line to push to the underlying code.InteractiveConsole. Must be valid Python

Return type

None

interact(prompt='Calculator')

Start an interactive prompt with the calculator

Parameters

prompt (str) – The prefix to each line on each interaction. Defaults to "Calculator"

Returns

Exits only on EOF, thus the program should not be expected to return. If it does, only cleanup and a swift exist should occur.

Return type

NoReturn

class symcalc.CalculatorContext

Contains all of the available methods and variables for a Calculator. The attribute CalculatorContext.__dict__ is meant to emulate globals()

Initializes the default calculator context

class symcalc.CalculatorCommand(calc, command)

Data for a single calculator command

Parameters

  • calc (symcalc.calc.Calculator) –

  • command (str) –

abort
resend_command
print_error
success

Directives to tell the Calculator what to do after the plugin returns. Setting abort and resend_command prevents further plugin processing of the command

command_original

The original command text before plugin processing

multiline_command

Whether the command is a multi-line command. Generally plugins never read True

buffer

The line buffer for a multi-line command

property command: str

The plaintext command. Setting this with CalculatorCommand.valid_syntax True updates the symbol table and the AST

Raises

SyntaxError – When setting the command to one with invalid Python syntax when CalculatorCommand.valid_syntax is True

property valid_syntax: bool

Whether the plaintext command is valid syntax. Setting this to True updates the symbol table and the AST

Raises

SyntaxError – If CalculatorCommand.command is not valid Python syntax when setting to True

property command_ast: ast.AST

The AST of the command. Setting this implies CalculatorCommand.valid_syntax and updates the plaintext command

Raises

ValueError – If CalculatorCommand.valid_syntax is False during read attempt

property command_symtable: symtable.SymbolTable

The symbol table of the command.

Raises

ValueError – If CalculatorCommand.valid_syntax is False during read attempt
